quam Regis meritissimi nataliciis convenire videantur, hodie vobis sim molestus futurus:
But do not fear that in presenting topics that seem more fitting for any other day than for the most deserving King's birthday, I will be a nuisance to you today.

non ita ineptus sum, ut aut illis litteris, quod nonnulli faciunt, immodice iactandis detrahere ceteris coner, illiberali et arroganti disputatione nihil aliud nisi nauseam audientibus facturus; neque eo usque exspatiabor, ut oratio mea reditum non inveniat:

I am not so foolish as to either excessively flaunt those literatures, as some do, thereby detracting from others with a vulgar and arrogant argument, only causing disgust to the listeners; nor will I digress so far that my speech will not find its way back.
continebo me in iis, quae a nemine vestrum plane aliena esse putem, qui omnes hac publicae institutionis parte potissima instructi estis;
I will contain myself to matters which I believe are not entirely foreign to any of you, all of whom are educated in this most important part of public instruction.

et quoniam nulla res a civitatis ratione prorsus seiungi potest, commode perveniam etiam eo, quo me fortasse prius accessurum sperabatis, ut ex iis, quae in hoc imperio bene instituta sunt, domui regnatrici et Principi benignissimo laudem quaeram.

And since no matter can be completely separated from the reasoning of the state, I will also conveniently arrive at what you perhaps hoped I would address earlier: to seek praise for the royal house and our most benevolent Prince from those things which are well established in this empire.
Denique, ut vos mihi aequi iudices adsitis, non expeto, nisi me oratorem haud iniquum esse cognoscetis.
Finally, I do not seek for you to be just judges of me, unless you recognize that I am a fair speaker.

Nam, ut ab hoc exordiar, qui in aliquo genere diutius elaborarunt atque in id animum penitus abdiderunt, non ego indignum iudico, si eidem plurimum tribuunt: quod nisi maximi aestimarent, mirum foret si non totum relinquerent atque ad alia omnia studium et industriam transferrent: attamen siquis nondum intellexerit, prout quisque ingenio feratur, aliis rebus alios excellere, et in universo eruditionis orbe nullam provinciam esse imperantem, nullam paullo ampliorem servientem, nullam unice praestare, ut reliquarum coloni quasi capite censeantur; is sciat se parum profecisse, nec litteras iusta mensura, sed pusillae suae mentis angusto admodum modulo metiri.

For, to begin from this point, those who have labored long in any field and have deeply immersed their minds in it, I do not deem it unworthy if they attribute much to the same field. If they did not value it highly, it would be strange if they did not abandon it entirely and transfer their enthusiasm and effort to all other pursuits. However, if anyone has not yet understood that, as each is inclined by their nature, different people excel in different things, and in the entire sphere of learning, there is no dominating province, no slightly larger subservient one, no one that excels uniquely so that the settlers of the others are regarded as head; let them know that they have made little progress and measure literature not by a just scale, but by the very narrow gauge of their small mind.

Scio fuisse et esse theologos, iuris peritos, medicos, philosophos, philologos, physicos, poetas, qui sese solos, quod operae pretium sit, scire, ceteros aut nihil aut nugatoria scire, et reliquas artes omnes flocci pendendas esse existiment: qui mihi hac ipsa iudicii superbia confiteri videntur, se plurima nescire: nam nisi quidquid ultra eius, quam amplexi sunt, disciplinae fines situm est plane ignorarent, vel externa illa leviter tantum attigissent et primoribus labris gustassent, singulis artibus cognovissent recte tractatis scientiam inesse profundissimam.

I am aware that there have been and are theologians, jurists, physicians, philosophers, philologists, physicists, poets, who think themselves to be the only ones who know anything worthwhile, considering others to know nothing or only trivialities, and deeming all other arts to be of little value. By this very arrogance in their judgment, they seem to confess to me that they are ignorant of many things. For if they were not completely unaware of whatever lies beyond the bounds of the discipline they have embraced, or if they had only lightly touched or barely tasted those external things, they would have recognized that in each art, when properly pursued, there is a profound depth of knowledge.

Sed ut in iis scholis, in quibus una aut altera doctrina separatim traditur, hanc suo seorsum loco superbire patiamur; certe in universitate litteraria, ubi unicuique arti doctores eximii dati sunt, siquis forte docentium ceteras disciplinas contemnat, eo est minus ferendus, quo facilius ex collegarum consortione errorem corrigere, et quo damnosior discipulis fieri potest.

But as in those schools where one or two subjects are taught separately, we may tolerate this pride in its own place; certainly in a literary university, where excellent teachers are appointed for each art, if someone among the teaching staff should happen to despise the other disciplines, he is all the less tolerable because he could more easily correct his mistake through the association with his colleagues, and because he can become more harmful to the students.

Etenim qui
solitarius vivit, quod aliena cum suis raro componit, frequentius eo adducetur, ut sua pluris, quam par est, habeat; contra nihil eruditum potest magis ad modestiam compellere, quam variarum artium quotidianus quasi adspectus: et qui discentes aliena obtrectando ab iis cognoscendis retrahit, earum rerum, quibus animum alant, magnam iis partem eripit.

Indeed, one who lives in solitude, because he rarely compares his own things with those of others, will more often be led to value his own things more than is appropriate. On the contrary, nothing can compel a person towards modesty more than the daily, as it were, sight of various arts. And the one who detracts from other subjects while teaching and deters students from learning about them, deprives them of a significant portion of things with which they could nourish their minds.

Quapropter de antiquitatis studio verba facturus id potissimum operam dabo, ut quod de illo in aliarum doctrinarum detrimentum praedicari falso solet, removeam diligenter, quum praesertim aliquid illi vulgo tribui intelligam, quod omnibus potius bonis artibus videatur commune esse.

Therefore, in speaking about the study of antiquity, I will particularly strive to carefully dispel the common misconception that it is detrimental to other disciplines, especially since I understand that it is generally attributed with something that seems to be common to all good arts.
Etenim invaluit, ut quae hac disciplina comprehenduntur, studia humanitatis vocarentur: unde quidam profecti huic litterarum generi humanitatem putarunt propriam et peculiarem esse.

Indeed, it has become customary to call the studies encompassed by this discipline the studies of humanity, from which some have concluded that humanity is inherent and unique to this genre of literature.
Quod tantum abest, ut verum censeam, ut a nulla scientia, quae hoc nomine digna sit, humanitatem arbitrer abesse posse.
But this is far from what I believe to be true, as I consider that no science, worthy of this name, can be devoid of humanity.

Nam primum ubi humanitatem credas in elegantia morum, in comitate, lenitate, lepore positam esse; nemo non intelligit aliquid, sed aliquid tantum, ad haec litteras quaslibet conferre, quod omnibus mores emolliuntur et cupiditates temperantur: immo qui in antiquitatis cognitione occupati sunt, ad istam vocis potestatem comparatos haud reperiri semper humanissimos, multi conquesti sunt.

For firstly, if you believe humanity lies in elegance of manners, in kindness, gentleness, charm, everyone understands that literature contributes something, but only something, to these qualities, as all literature softens manners and tempers desires. Indeed, those who are occupied in the knowledge of antiquity are not always found to be the most humane, as many have complained, when compared to this power of the word.

Quamquam equidem severitatem ac suo loco ipsam acerbitatem cum genuina humanitate pugnare aegre concesserim; quis enim in omnibus rebus et erga omnes obsequium probet? quis non potius vitia, malitiam, corruptos mores summa vi persequendos et perstringendos iudicet?

Although I would reluctantly admit that severity and even bitterness at times conflict with genuine humanity; for who approves of compliance in all things and towards everyone? Who would not rather judge that vices, malice, and corrupt manners should be pursued and sharply criticized with the greatest force?

Nam profecto qui se omnibus obsequiosum praestet, eum non tam humanum quam ignavum aut vulpeculae instar versutum fictumque dixerim; et Ciceronem Demosthenemque, licet in adversarios magno impetu irruentes, nemo tamen negaverit homines fuisse cultissimos.

For surely, one who presents himself as obliging to everyone, I would say is not so much humane as cowardly or cunning and insincere; and no one would deny that Cicero and Demosthenes, although they attacked their opponents with great force, were nevertheless very cultured men.

At maius quiddam et gravius humanitate comprehendi iudico, facultatem dico recte et ex praeceptis virtutis agendi, notiones rerum universas, quas ideas appellant, mente concipiendi, postremo ea, quae sentias, apte explicandi: quae quum homini sint propria, unice videntur humanitatis vim continere.

But I judge that something greater and more serious is encompassed by humanity, I mean the ability to act rightly and according to the precepts of virtue, to conceive in the mind the universal notions of things, which are called ideas, and finally, to aptly explain what you feel: since these are peculiar to human beings, they seem uniquely to contain the essence of humanity.
Iam vero quis tam stolidus est, ut in eo praesertim, qui nunc obtinet, eruditionis statu illa putet in solis antiquis litteris vel in his praecipue fundata esse?
Now, who is so foolish as to think that these, especially in the current state of education, are founded only or especially in ancient literature?

Ne enim de vita ad virtutem conformanda dicam, unicuique disciplinae insitas esse notiones purissimas, philosophiam autem his ipsis eminere, nisi
vanis commentis pessumdetur, non est quod demonstremus.

For not to speak of shaping life according to virtue, each discipline possesses its own purest notions, and philosophy stands out among these, unless it is brought down by vain comments, there is no need to demonstrate this.
Et quis theologiam secludere ab humanitate ausit, nisi qui deum ex homine exsulare iusserit?
And who would dare to separate theology from humanity, unless they commanded God to be exiled from man?
Iuris vero doctrina et medica ars, ut usui et experientiae, ita notionibus altissimis innixae sunt.
Indeed, the study of law and the art of medicine, as they are grounded in utility and experience, are also based on the highest notions.

Atque ut concedamus, perfectam philologiam potuisse nonnullis imprimis humanam videri, quae in ingenii operibus absolutissimis humani animi immensam profunditatem experiatur, et quidquid magnificum, generosum, dulce, suave est, quidquid hominum mentes commovet, percellit, componit, erigit, interiore cognitione comprehendat: tamen scriptae illae Musae non solae iucunditatem spirant; etiam florum calices corollasque inhabitat Venus et Gratia: Empedoclea illa principia, amor et odium, quibus homines ducuntur, etiam rerum naturam regunt, materias inanimas congregant et segregant, consociant, dissociant; et ratio per mundum universum diffusa in maximis minimisque divini fabricatoris operibus notionum formas et imagines menti ad illa intentae offundit.

And even if we grant that a perfected philology might seem particularly humane to some, experiencing the immense depth of the human mind in the most absolute works of genius, and comprehending whatever is magnificent, noble, sweet, pleasant, whatever moves, shakes, composes, and uplifts the minds of men with inner knowledge: yet those written Muses are not the only ones that breathe delight; Venus and Grace also dwell in the cups and corollas of flowers: those Empedoclean principles, love and hatred, which lead men, also govern the nature of things, gather and separate inanimate materials, associate and dissociate them; and reason, diffused throughout the entire world, pours into the mind, intent on those things, the forms and images of notions in both the greatest and smallest works of the divine creator.
Nec si cuperem, dicere possem, quo iure quaestiones grammaticae subtilissimae possent magis humanae haberi quam physicorum observationes microscopicae.
Nor could I say, even if I wished, by what right the most subtle grammatical questions could be considered more humane than the microscopic observations of natural scientists.

Quid quod universa antiquitatis studiorum materia, si linguas veteres exceperis, ipsis ceteris disciplinis continetur? quae nisi ad humanitatem pertinerent, non posset illud, quod inde compositum est, studium humanum vocari.

What about the fact that the entire subject matter for the studies of antiquity, except for the ancient languages, is contained in the other disciplines themselves? If these did not pertain to humanity, then that which is composed from them could not be called human study.

Nisi forte humanitatem in eo quaesiveris, ut in philologorum litteris sola singularum rerum initia tenuia tradantur, abstrusiora negligantur: quemadmodum Aristoteles liberaliter educandos artibus non ita institui voluit, ut in iis perfecti, sed ut rudimentis imbuti essent: quod ut de educatione liberali non male dictum est, ita non debet ad doctrinarum rationem iudicandam transferri.

Unless perhaps you seek humanity in this, that in the writings of philologists only the slender beginnings of individual things are conveyed, and the more profound aspects are neglected, just as Aristotle did not want those to be liberally educated in the arts to be perfected in them, but to be imbued with their rudiments: which, as it has been well said about liberal education, should not be transferred to the assessment of the doctrines.

Mihi quidem, ut satis significavi, humanitas imprimis in notionum videtur intelligentia cerni: quae ubi deficiunt, ibi incipere sellularium opificium arbitror; quo eorum ipsorum, qui antiquis litteris operam dant, teneri video haud paucos; omnes dico, qui maioribus impares, molem rerum et verborum rudem, inconditam, tenebricosam congerunt.

For me, as I have sufficiently indicated, humanity seems to be primarily seen in the understanding of notions: where these are lacking, there I think the work of a mere pedant begins; in which many of those who devote themselves to ancient literature are seen to be caught; I mean all those who, unequal to their predecessors, gather a mass of things and words that is rough, unpolished, and obscure.
Sed consideremus etiam illam humanitatis partem, quam in eo positam dixi, ut fari, quae sentias, possis.
But let us also consider that part of humanity which I have said lies in being able to express what you feel.

Ad quam non nego antiquarum litterarum studium prodesse eximie posse, quippe quod in scriptorum praestantissimorum exemplis perfectissimis verba, sententias, stilum, orationem spectet et examinet; attamen non tanta, quanta vulgo putatur,
haec est utilitas.

To which I do not deny that the study of ancient literature can be exceptionally beneficial, especially since it involves examining and studying words, sentences, style, and speech in the most perfect examples of the most excellent writers; however, its utility is not as great as is commonly thought.
Primum enim naturae maxime beneficio disertos fieri constat; sed accedere debet exercitatio, quae in antiquitatis studiosis solet perexigua esse.
For it is well known that eloquence is chiefly a gift of nature; but exercise must be added, which is often very slight in those devoted to the study of antiquity.
Dein critica et grammatica disciplina iudicium quidem format et fingit, sed a prompte disserendo magis revocat quam eam facultatem affert.
Then, critical and grammatical discipline indeed shapes and forms judgment, but it more often deters from the ability to speak on the subject with fluency than it provides that ability.

Enimvero plurimos, qui in illo genere diligentius versantur (nec me excipio), non magnopere in dicendo exercitatos esse, sed accurata et subtili sermonis disquisitione eo redigi videmus, ut et copia sententiarum eos deficiat, et ipsa oratio, quod vitia acrius perspiciunt et formidolosius cavent, sibi quasi diffidens minus fluat: fere ut Aristarchus, grammaticorum parens, interrogatus ut videtur, cur non ipse carmen componeret, quum carminum vitia et virtutes optime cognitas haberet, fertur respondisse, neque se posse scribere, quemadmodum vellet, neque velle, quemadmodum posset.

Indeed, many who are more diligently involved in that genre (and I do not exclude myself) are not greatly practiced in speaking, but we see them reduced by accurate and subtle examination of speech, so that they lack abundance of ideas, and the very speech, because they perceive faults more sharply and avoid them with more fear, flows less confidently, almost like Aristarchus, the father of grammarians, who, when asked why he did not compose a poem himself, although he knew well the faults and virtues of poems, is said to have replied that he could not write as he wished, nor did he wish to write as he could.
Alii optimis exemplaribus versandis hoc unum assecuti sunt, ut, quod Latinis maxime oratoribus exprobratur, multis verbis nihil dicant, vel ut Imperator Claudius eleganter sed inepte scribant.

Others, by dealing with the best examples, have achieved only this: that, for which Latin orators most of all have been criticized, they say nothing with many words, or write elegantly but inaptly, like Emperor Claudius.

Postremo si aequabilem virium animi cultum, quem antiquarum litterarum studia praestare dicuntur, nec tamen multis praestiterunt, humanitatis nomine vocare velis, illa ipsa aequabilis eruditio magis ex ingenii bonitate pendet, eoque erit perfectior, quo plura probe subacta et digesta mens cogitatione complecti potuerit; in quo summi erunt philosophi, siqui, quam indolis magnitudinem in Aristotele et Leibnitio fuisse scimus, universum doctrinarum orbem permeaverint.

Finally, if you wish to call that equal cultivation of the powers of the mind, which the studies of ancient literature are said to provide but have not provided to many, by the name of humanity, that very equal erudition depends more on the goodness of the intellect, and it will be more perfect, the more the mind can encompass many thoroughly subdued and digested thoughts; in which the greatest philosophers will be those who, like the greatness of character we know existed in Aristotle and Leibniz, have traversed the entire sphere of doctrines.

Quae quum ita sint, mitto eximium illum titulum litteris nostris impositum, et in eam, unde propagatus est, aetatem relego, qua Europae nationes ex barbariae inveteratae sordibus emergentes et in veterum auctorum contemplatione incalescentes hinc omnis melioris cultus semina petebant, qua summus poeta Dantes Aligherius Virgilium tamquam omnibus numeris absolutum artis suae specimen suspiciebat, Franciscus Petrarca de restituenda in communem usum Latina lingua cogitabat, qua in Platonis et Aristotelis libris unici sanioris philosophiae fontes scaturiebant; denique qua ad antiquorum scriptorum elegantiam Latino sermone aemulandam merito optima ingenia convertebantur: nunc adultis litteris aliter statuendum videtur.

Given these circumstances, I discard that distinguished title imposed on our literature, and I relegate it to the era from which it originated, when the nations of Europe, emerging from the filth of ingrained barbarism and warming in the contemplation of ancient authors, sought from them the seeds of all better culture, where the supreme poet Dante Alighieri admired Virgil as a model of his art perfected in all respects, Francesco Petrarca thought about restoring Latin language for common use, where in the works of Plato and Aristotle the springs of a uniquely healthier philosophy were bubbling; finally, where the best talents were rightly turned to emulate the elegance of ancient writers in Latin language: now, with literature matured, it seems appropriate to make a different decision.

Itaque ubi, quae et qualis philologia meo iudicio sit, quaeritis, simplicissima ratione respondeo, si non latiore, quae in ipso
vocabulo inest, potestate accipitur, sed ut solet ad antiquas litteras refertur, esse eam universae antiquitatis cognitionem historicam et philosopham.

Therefore, when you ask what philology is and what it should be in my opinion, I respond in the simplest way, that if it is not taken in the broader power inherent in the word itself, but as it is usually referred to ancient literature, it is the historical and philosophical knowledge of the whole of antiquity.

Universae inquam antiquitatis: quo distat quodammodo ab historia res ex ordine temporum gestas potissimum docente, quum philologia omnem antiquorum populorum vitam comprehendat eamque per partes quasque cognoscere conetur: quamquam qui rem acrius spectaverit, nullam inveniet philologiae partem, quin historiae possit argumentum fieri.

I speak of the whole of antiquity: in this, it somewhat differs from history, which primarily teaches things done in a chronological order, while philology encompasses the life of all ancient peoples and tries to understand it in each of its parts: although whoever looks more closely will find no part of philology that cannot become a subject for history.

Magnopere igitur errare mihi videntur, qui huius disciplinae fines ad interpretis et critici artes restringunt, quibus manifestum est non summos doctrinae fines, sed veri inveniendi instrumenta contineri: quod non in illarum artium contemptum, sed quod res ipsa postulat, dico, qui potius in illis aliquid reconditius, quam plurimi vident, inesse intelligam, modo ne criticam in solis corrigendis librariorum mendis positam arbitrentur, dum divam vocant, illius scilicet divinitatem exili isto usu suo ultro irridentes et prostituentes.

Therefore, it seems to me that they err greatly who restrict the limits of this discipline to the arts of the interpreter and critic, in which it is clear that not the highest goals of scholarship, but tools for finding truth are contained: this I say not in contempt of those arts, but as the matter itself demands, understanding that there is something more profound in them than many see, provided that they do not consider criticism to be solely concerned with correcting the errors of copyists, while calling it divine, they are actually mocking and debasing its divinity by such meager use.

Nec minus turpe iudico, siquis rudem variarum rerum congeriem pro philologia venditet: cui ubi philosopham cognitionem tribuo, hoc significo, summas esse notiones indagandas veteribus nationibus natura insitas et in singulis antiqui cultus partibus velut in adspectabilibus imaginibus expressas: quae notiones non ex arbitrio constituendae, quomodo recta via inveniri possint, nunc non exponam.

Nor do I judge it less disgraceful if someone peddles a crude assortment of various things as philology: to which, when I attribute philosophical knowledge, I mean that the highest notions, innate in the nature of ancient nations and expressed in each part of their ancient culture as if in visible images, must be investigated: these notions are not to be established arbitrarily, how they might be found by the right path, I will not now explain.

Iam ne in hac re sane magna, quod universae doctrinae caput dixerim, diutius immorer, ubi ad singulas partes perveneris, uniuscuiusque non modo bene digesta et idoneis testibus comprobata, sed summis illis notionibus congrua expositio reddenda est, ut, dum quaeque ante oculos panditur, non fortuito, sed interiore necessitate, quantum haec in rebus humanis inesse potest, ita conformatam et has decursu temporum vicissitudines expertam esse intelligamus.

Now, lest I dwell too long on this matter, which I consider the head of all doctrine, when you come to each part, an exposition must be rendered for each, not only well-digested and proven by suitable witnesses but also congruent with those highest notions, so that, as each thing is unfolded before our eyes, we understand it to be shaped not by chance but by an inner necessity, as much as this can exist in human affairs, and to have experienced these changes over the course of time.

Ipsas autem partes, suis rursum articulis dividendas, tribus verbis indico: primam rerum publice gestarum, cum temporum et locorum notitia, et institutorum civilium, etiam iuris cognitionem; alteram privatarum rerum, tertiam religionum artiumque demonstrationem; quartam doctrinarum omnium, philosophiae, moralium et naturalium disciplinarum, stilorum ac litterariorum generum historiam, postremo linguae, cui primitiva gentis scientia innata est, perfectam explicationem: quas partes cunctam philologiae materiam complectentes cur ita composuerim et disiunxerim, ampliorem exposcit indaginem.

But these parts themselves, to be divided again into their own sections, I indicate in three words: the first of public affairs, with knowledge of times and places, and civil institutions, even knowledge of law; the second of private matters, the third of the demonstration of religions and arts; the fourth of all doctrines, philosophy, moral and natural disciplines, the history of styles and literary genres, and finally the perfect explanation of the language to which the primitive knowledge of the nation is innate: these parts, encompassing the whole matter of philology, why I have so composed and separated them, demands a more extensive investigation.

Quodsi
antiquitatis studia in hunc modum delineaveris, non modo altissimam latissimamque illis eruditionem exerceri, sed ut plurimis artibus, ita etiam huic neminem unum sufficere concedes: immo qui in omnibus partibus perfectus fieri contenderit, eum in nulla summum assequi posse constat, quemadmodum, qui primus philologi nomine usus est, Eratosthenes in nulla re princeps, in omnibus secundus habitus est.

If you outline the studies of antiquity in this way, you will not only recognize that they involve the most profound and extensive erudition, but also concede that, like many arts, no single person is sufficient for this one: indeed, he who strives to be perfect in all its parts is seen to be able to reach the summit in none, just as Eratosthenes, who was first to use the name of philologist, was considered second in all things, never the foremost."

Dividendis operis hic quoque plurimum proficietur, quoniam, ut Hesiodus ait, dimidium plus toto; sed in quaqua singuli particula insigniorem collocant industriam, potissimis universae disciplinae notionibus debent instructi esse, ne opificum occupent locum.

Much is also gained by dividing the work, since, as Hesiod says, 'the half is more than the whole'; but wherever individuals place their distinguished effort in any part, they must be equipped with the principal notions of the entire discipline, lest they occupy the place of mere craftsmen.

Postremo quum certum esse videatur, ut Graeci cunctarum artium initia ad Homerum auctorem rettulerunt, ita omnes, quae nostris temporibus excultae sunt, artes in antiquitate radices habere; patet omnibus doctis communem esse philologiam, non iis, qui philologi appellantur, propriam, nec posse sine ceterarum disciplinarum adminiculo absolvi.

Lastly, as it seems certain that the Greeks traced the beginnings of all arts to Homer as their author, so all the arts that have been cultivated in our times have their roots in antiquity; it is clear to all the learned that philology is common, not proprietary to those called philologists, and cannot be completed without the aid of other disciplines.

Perfecisse mihi videor, quod volebam, auditores, ut ostenderem, nolle mea me studia praeter modum verbis exornare, sed communem me omnium eruditorum rem agere, ut par est in tanta apud nos variarum disciplinarum concordia, quarum nullam ceteris aut potiorem aut utiliorem esse etiam viri illi amplissimi iudicant, quos Pater patriae summo nostro commodo nobis praepositos esse voluit; simul id ex mea disputatione opinor colligi posse, non indignam esse antiquitatis doctrinam, quae multorum doctorum studiis colatur; etsi ne haec quidem perfecta est, siquis nostrae aetatis artibus contemptis nihil nisi antiqua cognoverit.

I seem to have accomplished what I wanted, listeners, to show that I do not wish to unduly adorn my studies with words, but to act in the common interest of all the learned, as is fitting in such a concord of various disciplines among us, of which none are considered more important or useful than others, even by those eminent men whom the Father of the Country wished to be set over us for our great benefit; at the same time, it can be gathered from my discussion that the doctrine of antiquity, cultivated by the studies of many learned men, is not unworthy; although it is not perfect if one knows only the ancient arts, disregarding those of our age.
Sed quum de ipsa antiquitatis scientia hucusque dixerim, transeo nunc ad id, quod ad publicam potissimum utilitatcm referatur.
But now, having spoken thus far about the knowledge of antiquity itself, I turn to that which relates especially to the public good.

Nam quum antiquis litteris, propagata ex priore aetate consuetudine, praecipuus in scholarum disciplina locus datus reperiatur; quaesitum est, rectene hoc institutum adhuc retineretur necne: quippe intellectum erat, quod supra exposui, etiam ceteras disciplinas humanitatis spargere semina.

For when ancient literature, propagated by custom from a previous age, is found to have a principal place in school discipline, it has been questioned whether this practice should still be retained or not: indeed, it was understood, as I have explained above, that other disciplines also spread the seeds of humanity.

Sed ne ad argumenta, quibus utrinque certatum est, descendam, neve exponam, quomodo, qui aliquam linguam in pueritia recte addiscit, non solum animi vires acerrime exerceat, sed etiam immensam notionum copiam quasi insciens imbibat: quae antiquis litteris in educanda iuventute praerogativa tribuitur, hoc imprimis fundamento niti videtur, quod, quidquid recens aetas
protulit eximii, non desierunt veteres potissimum scriptores classici esse, tenerique animi iis, quae optima sunt, debent imbui, ut pulcherrimis formis repleantur.

But lest I descend to the arguments with which both sides have contended, or explain how one who properly learns any language in childhood not only exercises the powers of the mind most keenly but also, as it were unwittingly, imbibes an immense quantity of notions: this prerogative, attributed to ancient literature in the education of youth, seems to rely primarily on the foundation that, whatever excellent things the recent age has produced, the ancient writers especially remain the classics, and young minds should be imbued with what is best, so that they may be filled with the most beautiful forms.

Video quidem, qui classici sint, dubitari posse; sed ut longam disquisitionem brevi praecidam, id dico classicum, quod quo magis consideres, eo magis placet, non classicum, quod etiamsi initio placuerit, assidua contemplatione evilescit.

I see indeed that who the classics are can be doubted; but to cut short a long disquisition, I say this: classic is that which the more you consider it, the more it pleases, not classic is that which, even if it pleases at first, becomes dull upon continual contemplation.

Nec de unius tantum hominis aut paucorum iudicio loquor: quod classicum est, succedentium ae- tatum consensu crescit senescens, si tamen quod semper viget senescit; ceterarum rerum gratiam ex novitate metimur.

And I speak not only of the judgment of one man or a few: what is classic grows old with the consensus of succeeding ages, if indeed that which is always vigorous can grow old; we measure the appeal of other things by their novelty.
Tempus probat omnia; tempore veteres illi scriptores probati sunt; et saeculorum iudicium in iis praesertim, quae publice instituuntur, haud minimi faciendum est, nec quidquam temere novandum.

Time tests all things; by time, those ancient writers have been proven; and the judgment of the ages, especially in matters of public instruction, must not be underestimated, nor should anything be rashly innovated.
At maiores nostros prudentissimos in antiquis auctoribus iuventuti tradendis etiam aliud spectasse, ex indiciis quibusdam coniicio.
But I surmise that our most prudent ancestors had another objective in mind in handing down ancient authors to the youth, based on certain indications.

Nam licet rerum naturam scrutari merito eximium habeatur, humanae tamen res homini proximae sunt; inter humana vero nihil hominibus communius est, nihil debet carius esse, quam illa societas a natura ipsa constituta, quae omnia hominis bona continet, civitas uniuscuiusque patria.

For although it is rightly considered excellent to investigate the nature of things, human affairs are closest to man; among human matters, nothing is more common to men, nothing should be dearer, than that society established by nature itself, which contains all the goods of man, the state of each person's homeland.

Atqui patriae caritas per universos prope veteres scriptores ita est diffusa, ut hunc antiquitatis quasi spiritum vitalem dixerim: evolve poetas, philosophos, oratores, rerum auctores; patriae, et sine qua patria esse nulla potest, libertatis amorem intimis omnium visceribus infixum esse reperies.

Moreover, love for the homeland is so diffused through almost all the ancient writers that I might call it the vital spirit of antiquity: examine poets, philosophers, orators, historians; you will find love for the homeland and liberty, without which no homeland can exist, deeply ingrained in the very core of them all.

Quod quum considero, nulla patriae historiae explicatione, in qua omnino claudicamus, quod praeclari ex hoc genere scriptores apud nostrates certas ob causas raro exsistunt, nulla legum et institutorum patriorum notitia, nullis publicis sollemnibus caritatem patriae et iustae libertatis sensus ita foveri ut veterum scriptorum lectione, puerosque illa disciplina recte instructos cum primis rudimentis, ipso Nepote legendo, praeclaris ali exemplis, haud cunctanter affirmo: quin etiam, quum praestantiores veteribus civilis prudentiae magistri inveniri nulli possint, non tantum pueri ex illis ad caritatem patriae, sed etiam viri ad res gerendas instituentur.

Considering this, I affirm without hesitation that no explanation of the history of the homeland, in which we altogether falter, as excellent writers of this kind rarely exist among our people for certain reasons, no knowledge of the laws and institutions of the homeland, no public ceremonies can nurture love for the homeland and a sense of just liberty as well as the reading of ancient writers, and that boys properly instructed in this discipline, with its first principles, by reading Nepos and other illustrious examples, not only will boys be guided to love their homeland, but even men will be educated for managing affairs, as no better masters of civil prudence than the ancients can be found.

Sed de hoc, quamquam summorum id hominum auctoritate et re ipsa comprobari potest, satius duco tacere, ne quod meae personae convenit, excedam: quod priore loco posui, conspicuis exemplis illustrare iuvat.

But about this, although it can be confirmed by the authority of the greatest men and by the fact itself, I think it better to remain silent, lest I exceed what befits my person; it is pleasing to illustrate with clear examples what I have placed first.
Fridericus Magnus et Neapolio Imperator documento sunto.
Let Frederick the Great and Emperor Napoleon serve as examples.

Quorum iste alter quum iniquae tyrannidi
infestam veterum scriptorum tractationem esse pro sua perspicacitate intelligeret, illa ipsi magnopere displicuit; Friderico Magno, huius imperii statori praecipuo, ut omnia quae animum alere et servitio liberare possent, sic Graecos Latinosque auctores imprimis placuisse et institutioni scholasticae esse aptissimos visos, res est notissima.

The latter, when he understood with his keen perception that the treatment of ancient writers was hostile to unjust tyranny, greatly disliked it; for Frederick the Great, the principal founder of this empire, it is well known that the Greek and Latin authors, as all that could nourish the mind and liberate it from servitude, were especially pleasing and seemed most suitable for scholastic instruction.

Qui in limine senectae, attritis corporis viribus sed mente integra, quum sibi optimos quosque scriptores Graecos assidue recitari iussisset, licet Gallicis potissimum litteris a Graecorum indole alienissimis esset excultus, ipsosque illos Graecos auctores vi sua fraudatos ex solis Gallicis interpretationibus nosceret; tamen illis egregie delectatus, et, ut in hoc uno consistam, in Demosthenis de corona oratione magnis sententiis et carissimo erga patriam affectu referta ingenii praestantiam admiratus est.

He, who on the threshold of old age, with his body's strength worn but his mind intact, ordered the best of Greek writers to be continually recited to him, although he was primarily nurtured on French literature, which is most alien to the Greek spirit, and knew those very Greek authors only through French translations, deprived of their own force; nevertheless, he was greatly delighted with them and, to focus on this one point, admired the brilliance of the intellect in Demosthenes' oration 'On the Crown', filled with grand sentiments and a most dear affection for the homeland.

Eundem scimus suis, non amicorum consiliis ductum iussisse, ut Graeci Latinique scriptores praecipui in scholis diligentissime legerentur, nec tantum verba adolescentulorum mandarentur memoriae, sed etiam rerum tractandarum ratio et res ipsae ac sententiae explicarentur.

We know that the same [Frederick the Great], led by his own, not friends' advice, ordered that the principal Greek and Latin writers be read most diligently in schools, and that not only the words be committed to the memory of the young, but also the method of handling matters and the matters themselves and sentiments be explained.

Ita Friderico Magno regnante in hoc imperio et in hac maxime urbe melioris disciplinae fundamenta certiora iacta sunt; quae instituta Fridericus Guilelmus, Rex noster sapientissimus, non modo retinuit sed firmavit; idem victo Europae communi hoste eam, quae ab isto imminebat, avertit barbariem.

Thus, during the reign of Frederick the Great in this empire and especially in this city, firmer foundations of a better discipline were laid; which institutions Frederick William, our most wise king, not only retained but also strengthened; the same, having defeated the common enemy of Europe, averted the barbarism that threatened from that source.
Quocirca non possum quin illud, de quo dixi, institutum praedicem: hoc enim pignus libertatis est.
Therefore, I cannot but extol the institution I have mentioned: for it is a pledge of liberty.

Quam qui ulla ex causa reformidarunt, ne scriptores illi iuventuti integri traderentur, caverunt; ut mutilarentur etiam animi, ne artus moveri possent: quamquam raro isti, quod cupiebant, assecuti sunt, quod, ut clarissimi scriptoris verba huic rei accommodem, praesenti potentia exstingui non potest sequentis aevi memoria.

Those who feared liberty for any reason prevented those writers from being handed down intact to the youth; they aimed to mutilate even the minds, so that the limbs could not move: although those rarely achieved what they desired, because, to adapt the words of a most illustrious writer to this matter, the memory of the following age cannot be extinguished by present power.

Neque vero quum adolescens progenies illis alimentis nutritur, rebus gerendis immiscetur, quibus veteres ipsi, suis huic rei annis constitutis, imparem habuerunt; sed a rerum praesentium contagione procul remota in aura pura versatur, quam spiritu ducere iuvenilis mens debet.

And indeed, when the young generation is nourished by those nourishments, it does not get involved in affairs of state, to which even the ancients themselves, at their years set for this purpose, were unequal; but it moves in a pure air, far removed from the contagion of present things, which the youthful mind ought to lead with spirit.

Quare errasse mihi magnopere videntur, qui, quum genuinos Germanos fingere vellent, antiquarum litterarum studiis magna ex parte tantum non infensi, illa aut expellenda aut finibus angustissimis circumscribenda existimarunt.
Therefore, those seem to me to have greatly erred who, when they wanted to create genuine Germans, almost hostile in large part to the studies of ancient literature, thought that it should be either expelled or confined within the narrowest limits.

Conservemus igitur hoc generis humani bonum commune, quo omnes aetates altae sunt: sed agamus etiam gratias Principi
clementissimo, quem tacite quidem semper, sed hodie palam veneramur, cuius auspiciis scholarum disciplina a viris illis praestantissimis, qui nobis quoque praefecti sunt, successu faustissimo adiuvatur.

Therefore, let us preserve this common good of humanity, by which all ages are nourished: but let us also give thanks to the most clement Prince, whom we always silently, but today openly, venerate, under whose auspices the discipline of schools is most successfully aided by those most excellent men, who are also appointed over us.

Ex quo intelligitur illos perspectum habere, quibus rebus vera populi salus fulta sit: nam ut ridiculum dicere videar, tamen dicam, non exercitus, non opes, non illustrissimos viros tanto esse civitati munimento, quanto bonos iuventutis magistros; inter quos nos quidem primi sumus, sed scholastici praeceptores, in quibus haud pauci ea doctrinae copia instructi sunt, ut etiam maioribus muneribus sufficiant, eo magis mihi remuneratione digni videntur, quo maior eorum molestia est et locus minus splendidus.

From this, it is understood that they had a clear perception of what truly supports the well-being of the people: for, as ridiculous as it may seem to say, I will say that not armies, not wealth, not the most illustrious men are as much a fortification to the state as good teachers of youth; among whom we indeed are foremost, but especially the school teachers, many of whom are so well-equipped with knowledge that they are sufficient for even greater tasks, and therefore seem to me all the more deserving of reward, the greater their trouble and the less splendid their position.

In universitatibus litterariis copiosius instruendis civitatium rectores non semper ab ostentatione videntur alieni fuisse, quod tanta illarum auctoritas olim habita est ac partim etiamnunc habetur, ut una universitate gloriari universum regnum possit: scholarum instituta minus conspicua ubi eadem cura digna putantur, non vanam speciem, sed ipsam rerum veritatem unice spectari constat.

In providing abundant instruction in literary universities, the rulers of states do not always seem to have been averse to ostentation, given the great authority these institutions once had and partly still hold, so much so that an entire kingdom can take pride in a single university. When less conspicuous school establishments are considered worthy of the same care, it is clear that not vain appearance but the very truth of things is uniquely regarded.

Sed Fridericus Guilelmus utraque gloria ornatus est, et universitatum summa cum munificentia eaque omnis iactationis experte institutarum atque amplissima supellectile ornatarum, quam nos potissimum illi debemus, et vero etiam scholarum magis magisque auctarum.

But Frederick William is adorned with both glories, both of the universities, established with the utmost generosity and without any ostentation and decorated with the most ample furnishings, which we owe chiefly to him, and indeed also of the increasingly enhanced schools.

Nobis autem quum ceteri civitatis ministri tum scholastici et ecclesiastici doctores formandi sunt, qui satisfacere rei publicae necessitalibus, satisfacere Regis benignissimi desideriis possint: quod officium quantum sit, nemo vestrum non intelligit.

For us, both the other ministers of the state and the scholastic and ecclesiastical teachers must be formed, who can satisfy the needs of the republic, satisfy the desires of the most benign King: the magnitude of this duty is understood by all of you.

Commovetur animus, auditores, ubi cogito, quantopere his praesertim temporibus, quibus omnium in nos oculi coniiciuntur, nobis allaborandum sit, ut conditoris nostri optimum quidque cupientis respondeamus votis: sed voluntatem nostram ubi viderit, quoniam nihil perfecti humanis viribus effici potest, iis quae infecta relinquuntur veniam dabit placide.

My spirit is stirred, listeners, when I think how much we must strive, especially in these times when all eyes are upon us, to meet the wishes of our founder who desires the very best: but when he sees our will, since nothing perfect can be achieved by human effort, he will calmly forgive what is left unfinished.
Commovetur animus, ubi quanta illi debeamus, uno in conspectu video; occluditur os, dum quid primum, quid secundum, quid tertium dicam, haesito.
My spirit is stirred when I see in one view how much we owe him; my mouth is closed, as I hesitate about what to say first, second, third.

Quapropter ut paucis haud pauca complectar, quidquid per tot annos de Rege carissimo hoc die et ex hoc ipso suggestu dixi: multa enim dixi, vobis testibus, quae non opinor a quoquam vestrum esse oblivioni tradita, quos scio mihi attentos semper auditores affuisse: quidquid igitur superioribus annis totiens dixi, id scitote omne in hoc temporis articulo mentem
meam implere; id animo repetite, atque inde coniecturam facite, quantum sit quod sentio.

Therefore, to encompass much in few words, whatever I have said over the years about our dearest King on this day and from this very podium: for I have said much, as you witnesses know, which I do not believe has been forgotten by any of you, who I know have always been attentive listeners: whatever I have thus said in previous years, know that it all fills my mind at this moment; recall it in your minds, and from there infer how great is what I feel.

His sensibus vos quoque repleti mecum precamini Deum bonorum omnium auctorem et conservatorem, ut caput illud sanctissimum nobis et rei publicae servet in extremam senectutem, et regiam domum universam integram, salvam, incolumem praestet perpetuo.

Filled with these sentiments, you too pray with me to God, the author and preserver of all good things, that He preserve that most holy head for us and for the republic into extreme old age, and grant the entire royal house to remain whole, safe, and unharmed forever.
